text: A thing cannot both be and not be at the same time in the same respect
If A equals B and B equals C then A equals C
A whole is equal to the sum of its parts
Two plus two equals four
A triangle has three sides
A square has four equal sides and four right angles
A circle is a set of points equidistant from a center point
Zero multiplied by any number equals zero
Any number divided by itself equals one
The square root of four is two
Parallel lines never intersect
A straight line is the shortest distance between two points
The sum of angles in a triangle equals 180 degrees
A prime number is divisible only by one and itself
One plus one equals two
Ten minus five equals five
Three times three equals nine
Eight divided by two equals four
The integer following three is four
Zero is neither positive nor negative
A cube has six faces
A sphere has no edges
A rectangle has four sides
An even number is divisible by two
An odd number is not divisible by two
The Pythagorean theorem states that a squared plus b squared equals c squared in a right triangle
A right angle measures 90 degrees
A full circle contains 360 degrees
The perimeter of a circle is called its circumference
The diameter of a circle is twice its radius
A pentagon has five sides
A hexagon has six sides
An octagon has eight sides
A cylinder has two circular bases
A cone has one circular base and one apex
The area of a rectangle equals length times width
The volume of a cube equals side length cubed
One meter equals 100 centimeters
One kilogram equals 1000 grams
One liter equals 1000 milliliters
One hour contains 60 minutes
One minute contains 60 seconds
One day contains 24 hours
One week contains seven days
January is the first month of the year
December is the twelfth month of the year
A leap year occurs every four years with exceptions
The alphabet contains 26 letters in English
A dozen equals twelve
A century equals 100 years
A millennium equals 1000 years
Multiplication is commutative
Addition is associative
The identity element for multiplication is one
The identity element for addition is zero
A negative times a negative equals a positive
A negative times a positive equals a negative
The absolute value of a number is non-negative
The square of any real number is non-negative
If x equals y then y equals x
A set is a collection of distinct objects
The empty set contains no elements
A subset contains only elements from its parent set
The union of two sets contains all elements from both sets
The intersection of two sets contains only common elements
An equilateral triangle has three equal sides
An isosceles triangle has at least two equal sides
A scalene triangle has no equal sides
An acute angle is less than 90 degrees
An obtuse angle is greater than 90 degrees and less than 180 degrees
Vertical angles are equal
Complementary angles sum to 90 degrees
Supplementary angles sum to 180 degrees
The area of a triangle equals one half base times height
A rhombus has four equal sides
A trapezoid has at least one pair of parallel sides
A parallelogram has two pairs of parallel sides
Opposite sides of a parallelogram are equal
The diagonals of a rectangle are equal
The diagonals of a square are equal and perpendicular
A polygon is a closed figure with straight sides
The sum of exterior angles of any polygon equals 360 degrees
A regular polygon has all sides and angles equal
A quadrilateral has four sides
The volume of a sphere equals four thirds pi times radius cubed
The surface area of a sphere equals four pi times radius squared
The circumference of a circle equals two pi times radius
The area of a circle equals pi times radius squared
One kilometer equals 1000 meters
One ton equals 1000 kilograms
Water freezes at zero degrees Celsius at standard pressure
Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius at standard pressure
Absolute zero is minus 273.15 degrees Celsius
The speed of light in vacuum is approximately 299792458 meters per second
The base of the natural logarithm e is approximately 2.71828
The golden ratio phi is approximately 1.618
One foot equals twelve inches
One yard equals three feet
One mile equals 5280 feet
One gallon equals four quarts
One pound equals sixteen ounces
There are twelve months in a year
February has 28 days in a common year
February has 29 days in a leap year
April has 30 days
May has 31 days
June has 30 days
July has 31 days
August has 31 days
September has 30 days
October has 31 days
November has 30 days
March has 31 days
January has 31 days
A year contains 365 days in a common year
A year contains 366 days in a leap year
The sum of two even numbers is even
The sum of two odd numbers is even
The sum of an even and odd number is odd
The product of two even numbers is even
The product of two odd numbers is odd
Zero is an integer
All natural numbers are integers
All integers are rational numbers
All rational numbers are real numbers
The square root of two is irrational
Pi is irrational
E is irrational
A function maps each input to exactly one output
The derivative measures rate of change
The integral measures accumulated quantity
The sine of zero degrees equals zero
The cosine of zero degrees equals one
The tangent of 45 degrees equals one
Sine squared plus cosine squared equals one
One radian equals approximately 57.3 degrees
Two pi radians equal 360 degrees
The logarithm of one to any base equals zero
The logarithm of a base to itself equals one
Any number to the power of zero equals one
Any number to the power of one equals itself
The factorial of zero equals one
The factorial of one equals one
The factorial of five equals 120
A binary number uses only digits zero and one
A hexadecimal number uses base sixteen
An octal number uses base eight
The decimal system uses base ten
Mass cannot be created or destroyed in a closed system
Energy cannot be created or destroyed in a closed system
The speed of light in vacuum is constant
Gravity attracts objects with mass toward each other
Electric charges of opposite sign attract each other
Electric charges of the same sign repel each other
Magnetic poles exist in pairs
Like magnetic poles repel each other
Opposite magnetic poles attract each other
Light travels in straight lines in a uniform medium
Sound requires a medium to travel
Heat flows from hot objects to cold objects
The wavelength times frequency of light equals its speed
Photons have no mass
Electrons have negative charge
Protons have positive charge
Neutrons have no charge
Atoms contain protons neutrons and electrons
The atomic number equals the number of protons
Hydrogen has atomic number one
Helium has atomic number two
Carbon has atomic number six
Nitrogen has atomic number seven
Oxygen has atomic number eight
Gold has atomic number 79
Iron has atomic number 26
Sodium has atomic number 11
Chlorine has atomic number 17
Uranium has atomic number 92
Water consists of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom
Carbon dioxide consists of one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms
Salt consists of sodium and chlorine
Momentum equals mass times velocity
Force equals mass times acceleration
Work equals force times distance
Power equals work divided by time
Kinetic energy equals one half mass times velocity squared
Potential energy in a gravitational field equals mass times gravitational acceleration times height
Pressure equals force divided by area
Density equals mass divided by volume
Velocity equals distance divided by time
Acceleration equals change in velocity divided by time
Electric current equals charge divided by time
Voltage equals current times resistance
Electric power equals voltage times current
The period of a wave is the inverse of its frequency
Wavelength equals speed divided by frequency
Objects in motion remain in motion unless acted upon by force
Objects at rest remain at rest unless acted upon by force
For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction
The gravitational force between two objects is proportional to their masses
The gravitational force between two objects is inversely proportional to the square of their distance
Light exhibits wave properties
Light exhibits particle properties
The electromagnetic spectrum includes radio waves
The electromagnetic spectrum includes microwaves
The electromagnetic spectrum includes infrared radiation
The electromagnetic spectrum includes visible light
The electromagnetic spectrum includes ultraviolet radiation
The electromagnetic spectrum includes X-rays
The electromagnetic spectrum includes gamma rays
Red light has longer wavelength than blue light
Ultraviolet light has shorter wavelength than visible light
Infrared light has longer wavelength than visible light
The Sun emits electromagnetic radiation
Radioactive decay releases particles or energy
Alpha particles consist of two protons and two neutrons
Beta particles are electrons or positrons
Gamma rays are high energy photons
Half life is the time for half of a radioactive sample to decay
Temperature measures average kinetic energy of particles
Absolute zero is the lowest possible temperature
Gases expand when heated at constant pressure
Liquids expand when heated
Most solids expand when heated
Ice is less dense than liquid water
Pressure increases with depth in a fluid
Buoyant force equals the weight of displaced fluid
The speed of sound in air is approximately 343 meters per second at room temperature
The speed of sound increases with temperature
Doppler effect changes observed frequency with relative motion
Refraction bends light passing between different media
Reflection bounces light off surfaces
The angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection
Total internal reflection occurs at angles beyond the critical angle
A convex lens converges light rays
A concave lens diverges light rays
A convex mirror produces virtual images
A concave mirror can produce real or virtual images
White light separates into colors through a prism
The visible spectrum ranges from red to violet
Chlorophyll absorbs red and blue light
Friction opposes motion between surfaces
Air resistance opposes motion through air
Terminal velocity occurs when forces balance
Centripetal force is required for circular motion
Angular momentum is conserved in isolated systems
Torque equals force times lever arm distance
The moment of inertia depends on mass distribution
Resonance occurs when driving frequency matches natural frequency
Standing waves have nodes and antinodes
Interference can be constructive or destructive
Diffraction spreads waves passing through openings
Polarization restricts wave oscillation to specific directions
Photoelectric effect releases electrons when light hits metal
Blackbody radiation spectrum depends on temperature
Wien displacement law relates peak wavelength to temperature
Stefan Boltzmann law relates radiated power to temperature
Entropy increases in isolated systems
Heat engines cannot be 100 percent efficient
Carnot efficiency depends on temperature difference
PV equals nRT for ideal gases
Boyle law states pressure times volume is constant at constant temperature
Charles law states volume divided by temperature is constant at constant pressure
Avogadro number is approximately 6.022 times ten to the 23rd power
One mole contains Avogadro number of particles
Molecular mass is measured in atomic mass units
pH measures hydrogen ion concentration
pH seven is neutral
pH below seven is acidic
pH above seven is basic
Strong acids completely dissociate in water
Oxidation is loss of electrons
Reduction is gain of electrons
Catalysts speed reactions without being consumed
Activation energy is required to start reactions
Exothermic reactions release energy
Endothermic reactions absorb energy
Chemical equilibrium occurs when forward and reverse rates equal
Le Chatelier principle describes equilibrium shifts
Ionic bonds involve electron transfer
Covalent bonds involve electron sharing
Metallic bonds involve delocalized electrons
Hydrogen bonds are weak electrostatic interactions
Van der Waals forces are weak intermolecular forces
Noble gases have complete outer electron shells
Halogens have seven valence electrons
Alkali metals have one valence electron
Alkaline earth metals have two valence electrons
Carbon can form four covalent bonds
Diamond is a form of carbon
Graphite is a form of carbon
Metals conduct electricity
Metals conduct heat
Insulators do not conduct electricity well
Semiconductors have intermediate conductivity
Superconductors have zero electrical resistance below critical temperature
Plasma is ionized gas
Sublimation converts solid directly to gas
Deposition converts gas directly to solid
Evaporation converts liquid to gas
Condensation converts gas to liquid
Melting converts solid to liquid
Freezing converts liquid to solid
Triple point is where all three phases coexist
Critical point is where liquid and gas phases become indistinguishable
Isotopes have same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons
Nuclear fission splits heavy nuclei
Nuclear fusion combines light nuclei
Antimatter has opposite charge to matter
Electron mass is approximately 9.109 times ten to the minus 31st kilograms
Proton mass is approximately 1.673 times ten to the minus 27th kilograms
Planck constant is approximately 6.626 times ten to the minus 34th joule seconds
Gravitational constant is approximately 6.674 times ten to the minus 11th newton meters squared per kilogram squared
Elementary charge is approximately 1.602 times ten to the minus 19th coulombs
The Earth orbits the Sun
The Moon orbits the Earth
Planets orbit in elliptical paths
Tides result from gravitational forces of the Moon and Sun
Day and night result from Earth rotation
Seasons result from Earth axial tilt
The Sun is a star
Stars produce energy through nuclear fusion
Red giant stars have expanded outer layers
White dwarf stars are dense stellar remnants
Neutron stars are extremely dense
Black holes have escape velocities exceeding light speed
Galaxies contain billions of stars
The Milky Way is a spiral galaxy
The universe is expanding
Cosmic microwave background radiation pervades space
Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun
Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system
Saturn has prominent rings
Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun
Venus is the second planet from the Sun
Earth is the third planet from the Sun
Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun
Neptune is the eighth planet from the Sun
Comets have tails pointing away from the Sun
Asteroids are rocky bodies orbiting the Sun
Meteoroids are small rocky or metallic bodies in space
Meteors are meteoroids burning in atmosphere
Meteorites are meteors that reach the ground
Living organisms require energy to maintain themselves
Cells are the basic units of life
DNA carries genetic information
Proteins are built from amino acids
Enzymes are biological catalysts
Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy
Cellular respiration releases energy from glucose
Mitochondria are organelles involved in energy production
Chloroplasts are organelles where photosynthesis occurs
The nucleus contains genetic material
Cell membranes control passage of substances
Diffusion moves substances from high to low concentration
Osmosis is diffusion of water across membranes
Active transport requires energy
DNA consists of nucleotides
The four DNA bases are adenine thymine guanine and cytosine
RNA contains uracil instead of thymine
DNA forms a double helix structure
Genes are segments of DNA
Chromosomes contain DNA
Humans have 46 chromosomes
Meiosis produces gametes
Mitosis produces identical daughter cells
Genetic mutations are changes in DNA sequence
Natural selection acts on heritable variation
Organisms reproduce to create offspring
Species share common ancestors
Fossils are preserved remains of ancient organisms
The tree of life shows evolutionary relationships
Bacteria are prokaryotic organisms
Eukaryotic cells have nuclei
Viruses require host cells to replicate
Fungi include yeasts and molds
Plants produce oxygen through photosynthesis
Animals consume organic matter for energy

Birds have feathers
Reptiles have scales
Amphibians undergo metamorphosis
Fish have gills
Arthropods have exoskeletons
Insects have six legs
Spiders have eight legs
Mollusks include snails and octopuses

Producers convert sunlight into chemical energy
Consumers obtain energy by eating other organisms
Decomposers break down dead organic matter
Food chains show energy flow
Food webs show interconnected feeding relationships
Predators hunt prey
Herbivores eat plants
Carnivores eat meat
Omnivores eat both plants and animals
Populations consist of individuals of the same species
Communities contain multiple species
Biomes are large ecological regions
Deserts receive low precipitation
Rainforests have high biodiversity
Tundra exists in cold climates
Grasslands support grazing animals
Oceans cover most of Earth surface
Coral reefs support diverse marine life
Wetlands filter water
Rivers flow toward oceans or lakes
Lakes are inland bodies of water
Groundwater exists beneath the surface
The water cycle involves evaporation and precipitation
Carbon cycles through atmosphere oceans and organisms
Nitrogen is essential for proteins
Phosphorus is essential for DNA and ATP
The atmosphere contains nitrogen and oxygen
Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas
Methane is a greenhouse gas
Water vapor is a greenhouse gas
Ozone absorbs ultraviolet radiation
The ozone layer exists in the stratosphere
Weather describes short term atmospheric conditions
Climate describes long term atmospheric patterns
Temperature varies with altitude
Humidity measures water vapor in air
Wind results from pressure differences
Clouds form from condensed water vapor

Snow forms when water vapor freezes
Hurricanes are large rotating storms
Tornadoes are rotating columns of air
Lightning is electrical discharge
Thunder results from lightning heating air
Earthquakes result from tectonic movement
Volcanoes erupt molten rock

Mountains form from tectonic uplift
Erosion wears down rock
Sediment accumulates in layers

Sedimentary rocks form from compressed sediment
Metamorphic rocks form from heat and pressure
Minerals have crystalline structure
Quartz is silicon dioxide
Calcite contains calcium carbonate
Diamonds are extremely hard
The Earth has layers
The crust is the outermost layer
The mantle lies beneath the crust
The core is at Earth center
The inner core is solid
The outer core is liquid
Earth magnetic field extends into space
The magnetosphere protects from solar wind
Solar flares emit radiation
Sunspots are dark regions on the Sun
The Sun rotates
Solar eclipses occur when the Moon blocks the Sun
Lunar eclipses occur when Earth blocks sunlight to the Moon
The Moon has phases
Full moon occurs when the Moon is opposite the Sun
New moon occurs when the Moon is between Earth and Sun
